sen.j: 寺子屋（てらこや）とは、江戸時代の庶民を対象とした教育施設である。
sen.e: Terakoya were educational institutes for ordinary citizens during the Edo period.
Terakoya were educational institutes for ordinary citizens during the Edo period.
Terakoya were educational institutes for ordinary citizens during the Edo period.

sen.j: 僧侶や武士や医師などが、庶民の子弟に読み書きそろばんや実務上の知識・技能を教育した施設をいう。
sen.e: Monks, bushi (samurai) and doctors taught reading, writing, soroban (using an abacus), and other practical knowledge and skills to children of ordinary citizens at these institutes.
Monks, bushi (samurai) and doctors taught reading, writing, soroban (using an abacus), and other practical knowledge and skills to children of ordinary citizens at these institutes.
Monks, bushi (samurai) and doctors taught reading, writing, soroban (using an abacus), and other practical knowledge and skills to children of ordinary citizens at these institutes.

sen.j: 手習い所や手習塾ともいう。
sen.e: Also called Tenarai-dokoro orTenarai-jyuku
Also called Tenarai-dokoro or Tenarai-jyuku.
Also called Tenarai-dokoro or Tenarai-juku.

sen.j: 寺子屋の起源は、中世の寺院での教育に遡ると言われる。
sen.e: The origin of Terakoya is said to be traced to education at temples and shrines during the middle ages.
The origin of Terakoya is said to be traced to education at temples and shrines during the middle ages.
The origin of Terakoya is said to be traced to education at temples and shrines during the middle ages.

sen.j: その後、江戸時代に入り、商工業の発展や社会に浸透していた文書主義などにより、実務教育の需要が一層高まり、先ず江戸や京都などの都市部に寺子屋が普及して行った。
sen.e: Later, in the Edo period, with the development of commerce and trade, and with the rise in importance of documents, the demand for practical education grew, which led to the spread of Terakoya initially in city areas such as Edo and Kyoto.

Later, in the Edo period, with the development of commerce and trade, and with the rise in importance of documents, the demand for practical education grew, which led to the spread of Terakoya initially in city areas such as Edo and Kyoto.

Later, in the Edo period, with the development of commerce and trade, and with the rise in importance of documents, the demand for practical education grew, which led to the spread of Terakoya initially in city areas such as Edo and Kyoto.

sen.j: 寛政年間（1690年代）頃から農村や漁村へも広がりを見せ始め、江戸時代中期（18世紀）以降に益々増加し、特に江戸時代後期の天保年間（1830年代）前後に著しく増加した。
sen.e: From the 1690s, it spread to agricultural and fishing villages, and became even more widespread after the middle of the Edo period (eighteenth century), especially around the Tenpo years (1830s) during the late Edo period.

From the 1690s, it spread to agricultural and fishing villages, and became even more widespread after the middle of the Edo period (eighteenth century), especially around the Tenpo years (1830s) during the late Edo period.

From the 1690s, it spread to agricultural and fishing villages, and became even more widespread after the middle of the Edo period (eighteenth century), especially around the Tenpo era (1830s) during the late Edo period.

sen.j: 又、経営形態も職業的経営に移行する傾向を見せた。
sen.e: There also was a trend for management to become more occupational.
There also was a trend for management to become more occupational.
There also was a trend for management to become more occupational.

sen.j: 寺子屋の教師（師匠）には、僧侶・神官・医師・武士・浪人・書家・町人などが多かった。
sen.e: The teacher (shisho) of Terakoya were often monks, priests, doctors, bushi, ronin(masterless samurai), calligraphers and townspeople.
The teachers (shisho) of Terakoya were often monks, priests, doctors, bushi, ronin (masterless samurai), calligraphers, and townspeople.
The teachers (shisho) of Terakoya were often monks, priests, doctors, bushi, ronin (masterless samurai), calligraphers, and townspeople.

sen.j: 修学者の多くが、各地の寺子屋教師となっていた足利学校のように、寺子屋の教師を養成する学校すらあった。
sen.e: Many students that finished there schooling went on to schools to train teachers for Terakoya such as the Ashikaga gakko, which trained Terakoya teachers who taught throughout Japan.
sen.cmt: 原文がやや不明、「修学者が足利学校のような教師養成学校へ通い、教師になった」と訳しました。
sen.e: Many students that finished their schooling went on to schools to train teachers for Terakoya such as the Ashikaga gakko, which trained Terakoya teachers who taught throughout Japan.
Many students that finished their schooling went on to schools to train teachers for Terakoya such as the Ashikaga gakko, which trained Terakoya teachers who taught throughout Japan.

sen.j: また今日の塾と違い、当時の寺子屋の師匠は、往々にして一生の師である例も多かった。
sen.e: In addition, different from jyuku (after-school lessons) of the present, a shisho of Terakoya was often a mentor for life.
In addition, different from jyuku (after-school lessons) of the present, a shisho of Terakoya was often a mentor for life.
In addition, different from juku (after-school lessons) of the present, a shisho of Terakoya was often a mentor for life.

sen.j: 寺子屋の生徒を「筆子」といい、師匠が死んだ時には、筆子が費用を出し合って師匠の墓を建てる事が珍しくなかった。
sen.e: The students of a Tergoya were called "Fudeko" and when the shisho died, the Fudeko would chip in to pay for the shisho's grave.
The students of a Tergoya were called "Fudeko" and when the shisho died, the Fudeko would chip in to pay for the shisho's grave.
The students of a Terakoya were called 'Fudeko' and when the shisho died, the Fudeko would chip in to pay for the shisho's grave.
sen.cmt: Tergoya→Terakoyaに修正、シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: そのような墓を筆子塚といい、房総半島だけでも3350基以上の筆子塚が確認されている。
sen.e: These graves are called Fudekoduka, and there are over 3,350 graves confirmed to be Fudekoduka just in the Boso Penninsula.
These graves are called Fudekoduka, and there are over 3,350 graves confirmed to be Fudekoduka just in the Boso Penninsula.
These graves are called Fudekozuka, and there are over 3,350 graves confirmed to be Fudekozuka just in the Boso Penninsula.

sen.j: 寺子屋では、「読書算」と呼ばれる読書・習字・算数の基礎的な知識の習得に留まらず、地理・人名・書簡の作成法など、実生活に必要とされる内容の教育が総合的に行われていた。
sen.e: The Terakoya not only taught basic reading, writing and calculation, but also a comprehensive curriculum that included subjects required for daily life such as geography, people names and preparing letters.

The Terakoya not only taught basic reading, writing and calculation, but also a comprehensive curriculum that included subjects required for daily life such as geography, people names and preparing letters.

The Terakoya not only taught basic reading, writing and calculation, but also a comprehensive curriculum that included subjects required for daily life such as geography, people names and preparing letters.

sen.j: 教育は第一に数字の習得から始まり、次いで文字の習得が為される事が多かった。
sen.e: Education first started with learning numbers and then went on to writing.
Education first started with learning numbers and then went on to writing.
Education first started with learning numbers and then went on to writing.

sen.j: そして、実生活に必要とされる知識や技術の教育が行われた。
sen.e: Then the students received education on knowledge and skills required for daily life.
Then the students received education on knowledge and skills required for daily life.
Then the students received education on knowledge and skills required for daily life.

sen.j: 「寺子屋」の名称は主に上方（京都・大坂・伊勢市など）で用いられ、江戸では「手習指南所」「手跡指南」などと呼ばれた。
sen.e: Terakoya was the name used mostly at Kamigata (Kyoto, Osaka, Ise) and it was called "Tenarai-shinanjo""Tesekishinann" in Edo.
Terakoya was the name used mostly at Kamigata (Kyoto, Osaka, Ise) and it was called "Tenarai-shinanjo" of "Tesekishinann" in Edo.
Terakoya was the name used mostly at Kamigata (Kyoto, Osaka, Ise) and it was called 'Tenarai-shinanjo' or 'Shuseki-shinan' in Edo.
sen.cmt: of→or、Tesekishinann→Shuseki-shinanに修正、クオーテーション表記修正

sen.j: 寺子屋の「子屋」が「こや（小屋）」に通じる点や、「屋」が屋号に通じる事が教育の場の名称に適切ではないと考えられたからである。
sen.e: This was because "Koya" in Terakoya sounds like "shed " and "Ya" sounds like a shop name and was considered unsuitable as a name for a place of education.
This was because "Koya" in Terakoya sounds like "shed" and "Ya" sounds like a shop name and was considered unsuitable as a name for a place of education.
This was because 'Koya' in Terakoya sounded like 'shed' and 'Ya' sounded like a shop name and was considered unsuitable as a name for a place of education.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、クォーテーションをシングル・半角に修正、sounds→soundedとしました。

sen.j: 幕末に内外の緊張が高まると、浪人の再就職（仕官）が増えた事により、町人出身の師匠の比率が増えた。
sen.e: When tension both internally and externally increased near the end of the Edo period, ronin found more work(in government service) and the ratio of shisho who were townspeople rose.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When tension both internally and externally increased near the end of the Edo period, ronin found more work (in government service) and the ratio of shisho who were townspeople rose.
When tension both internally and externally increased near the end of the Edo period, ronin found more work (in government service) and the ratio of shisho who were townspeople rose.

sen.j: また国学の初歩である古典を教える寺子屋も増えるなど、時代状況に応じて寺子屋も少しずつ変化を遂げて行った。
sen.e: Terakoya that taught Koten (classics) which is the basics of Kokugaku also increased, and Terakoya gradually changed with the times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Terakoya that taught Koten (classics) which is the basics of Kokugaku also increased, and Terakoya gradually changed with the times.
Terakoya that taught Koten (classics) which was the basics of Kokugaku also increased, and Terakoya gradually changed with the times.

sen.j: 明治維新期の1872年に学制が敷かれると、寺子屋は次第に消滅して行った。
sen.e: When in 1872, the school system was put in place by the Meiji Restoration, Terakoya gradually ceased to exist.
When in 1872, the school system was put in place by the Meiji Restoration, Terakoya gradually ceased to exist.
When in 1872, the school system was put in place by the Meiji Restoration, Terakoya gradually ceased to exist.

sen.j: しかし、寺子屋によって実務的な教育が庶民の間に定着しており、明治初期における日本の識字率は世界最高水準にあった。
sen.e: However, practical education by Teragoya had been entrenched among the ordinary citizens and the literacy level of the Japanese in the beginning of the Meiji period was among the top in the world.
However, practical education by Terakoya had been entrenched among the ordinary citizens and the literacy level of the Japanese in the beginning of the Meiji period was among the top in the world.
However, practical education by Terakoya had been entrenched among the ordinary citizens and the literacy level of the Japanese in the beginning of the Meiji period was among the top in the world.

sen.j: 明治期の日本が急速に近代化を達成できた要因のひとつに、寺子屋が庶民に高い教育水準をもたらしていた背景をあげることができる。
sen.e: One of the factors that led to the rapid modernization of Japan in the Meiji era was the high educational standards that Terakoya had provided the ordinary citizens.
One of the factors that led to the rapid modernization of Japan in the Meiji era was the high educational standards that Terakoya had provided the ordinary citizens.
One of the factors that led to the rapid modernization of Japan in the Meiji period was the high educational standards that Terakoya had provided the ordinary citizens.

sen.j: 教材
sen.e: Educational material
Educational material
Educational material

sen.j: 教科書としては、『庭訓往来』『商売往来』『百姓往来』など往来物のほか、文字を学ぶ『千字文』、人名が列挙された『名頭』『苗字尽』、地名・地理を学ぶ『国尽』『町村尽』、『四書五経』『六諭衍義』などの儒学書、『国史略』『十八史略』などの歴史書、『唐詩選』『百人一首』『徒然草』などの古典が用いられた。
sen.e: Text books included Oraimono such as Teikin Orai (collection of letters used for family education), Shobai Orai (A Guide to Commerce), Hakusho Orai (A Guide to Farming), Senjimon (a poem consisting of one thousand Chinese characters) for learning characters, Nagashira, Myojidukushi for learning names of people, Kunidukushi, Chosondukushi, for learning place names and geography, Shishogokyo, Rikuyuengi forConfucianism, and history books such as Kokushiryaku, Jyuhasshiryaku and classics such as Toshisen, Hyakuninishu and Tsureduregusa.

Text books included Oraimono such as Teikin Orai (collection of letters used for family education), Shobai Orai (a Guide to Commerce), Hakusho Orai (a Guide to Farming), Senjimon (a poem consisting of one thousand Chinese characters) for learning characters, Nagashira, Myojidukushi for learning names of people, Kunidukushi, Chosondukushi, for learning place names and geography, Shishogokyo, Rikuyuengi for Confucianism, and history books such as Kokushiryaku, Jyuhasshiryaku and classics such as Toshisen, Hyakuninishu and Tsureduregusa.

Text books included Oraimono such as "Teikin Orai" (collection of letters used for family education), "Shobai Orai" (a Guide to Commerce), "Hakusho Orai" (a Guide to Farming), "Senjimon" (a poem consisting of one thousand Chinese characters) for learning characters, "Nagashira," "Myojizukushi" for learning names of people, "Kunizukushi," "Chosonzukushi," for learning place names and geography, "Shishogokyo," "Rikuyuengi" for Confucianism, and history books such as "Kokushiryaku," "Juhasshiryaku" and classics such as "Toshisen," "Hyakuninisshu" and "Tsurezuregusa."
sen.cmt: Myojizukushi、Kunizukushi、 Chosondukushi、Juhasshiryaku、Hyakuninisshu、Tsurezuregusaに修正、原文表記に合わせクォーテーション追加

sen.j: 中でも往復書簡を集めた形式の書籍である往来物は特に頻用され、様々な書簡を作成する事の多かった江戸時代の民衆にとっては実生活に即した教科書であり、「往来物」は教科書の代名詞ともなった。
sen.e: Oraimono, collection of correspondence were frequently used as textbooks because the public during the Edo period often prepared various letters for practical life and eventually "Oraimono" became a pronoun for textbook.

Oraimono, collection of correspondences were frequently used as textbooks because the public during the Edo period often prepared various letters for practical life and eventually "Oraimono" became a pronoun for textbook.

Oraimono, collection of correspondences were frequently used as textbooks because the public during the Edo period often prepared various letters for practical life and eventually 'Oraimono' became a pronoun for textbook.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 就学者
sen.e: Students
Students
Students

sen.j: 寺子屋の就学年齢や卒業時期は、特に定まっていた訳ではなく、およそ5～6歳で就学し、13～14歳から18歳になる頃まで修学する例が多かった。
sen.e: The starting age and graduation age at Terakoya was not particularly fixed, and many started at around 5 to 6 and graduated around 13 to 14, up to 18 years of age.
The starting age and graduation age at Terakoya was not particularly fixed, and many started at around 5 to 6 and graduated around 13 to 14, up to 18 years of age.
The starting age and graduation age at Terakoya was not particularly fixed, and many started at around 5 to 6 and graduated around 13 to 14, up to 18 years of age.

sen.j: 男子限定や女子限定の寺子屋も少なくはなかったが、男女共学の寺子屋が多数であった。
sen.e: There were some Terakoya which only took boys or girls, but most Terakoya were coed.
There were some Terakoya which only took boys or girls, but most Terakoya were coed.
There were some Terakoya which only took boys or girls, but most Terakoya were coed.

sen.j: 江戸における嘉永年間（1850年頃）の就学率は70～86%といわれており、イギリスの主な工業都市で20～25%（1837年）、フランス1.4%（1793年）、ソビエト連邦20%（1920年、モスクワ）と、外国に比べ就学率が高かった。
sen.e: The percentage of children attending school was about 70 to 86 % in the Edo period around 1850s, and was higher compared to foreign countries such 20 to 25% for major industrial cities in Britain (1837), 1.4% for France (1793) and 20% for the Soviet Union (1920, Moscow).

The percentage of children attending school was about 70 to 86 % in the Edo period around 1850s, and was higher compared to foreign countries such 20 to 25% for major industrial cities in Britain (1837), 1.4% for France (1793) and 20% for the Soviet Union (1920, Moscow).

The percentage of children attending school was about 70 to 86 % in the Edo period around 1850s, and was higher compared to foreign countries such as 20 to 25% for major industrial cities in Britain (1837), 1.4% for France (1793) and 20% for the Soviet Union (1920, Moscow).
sen.cmt: countries such→countries such asとしました。

sen.j: 幕末期には、江戸に約1500校、全国では約15000校の寺子屋が存在した。
sen.e: By the end of the shogunate, there were 1,500 schools in Edo, and a total of 15,000 Terakoya throughout Japan.
By the end of the shogunate, there were 1,500 schools in Edo, and a total of 15,000 Terakoya throughout Japan.
By the end of the shogunate, there were 1,500 schools in Edo, and a total of 15,000 Terakoya throughout Japan.

sen.j: 1校辺りの生徒数は、10人から100人と様々であった。
sen.e: The number of students per school varied from 10 to 100.
The number of students per school varied from 10 to 100.
The number of students per school varied from 10 to 100.

tit.j: ユネスコ世界寺子屋運動

sen.j: 寺子屋を世界中に普及させようとしている運動が、国際連合教育科学文化機関が提唱している世界識字教育運動の1つであるユネスコ世界寺子屋運動（World Terakoya Movement）である。
sen.e: A movement to establish Terakoya throughout the world as part of improving literacy in the world is the World Terakoya Movement by UNESCO.
A movement to establish Terakoya throughout the world as part of improving literacy in the world is the World Terakoya Movement by UNESCO.
A movement to establish Terakoya throughout the world as part of improving literacy in the world is the World Terakoya Movement by UNESCO.
